question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. If no such enforcement meeting these criteria is confirmed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Philippine authorities implement a closure of online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are verified reports indicating that the Philippine authorities have effectively implemented a closure of online trading platforms run by Chinese entities in the Philippines. The implementation must be documented by at least two credible international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official actions taken by the government that result in the cessation of operations for a considerable number of these trading platforms. 'Considerable' in this context refers to at least 50% of the identified Chinese-operated online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time the enforcement occurs. The closure must stem from a governmental policy or directive, rather than voluntary shutdowns or economic circumstances. If there are no confirmed reports of such an enforcement meeting these specifications by the resolution date, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (1) The IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million, and (2) The Philippine government does not enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (1) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases), reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. (2) There are no confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines, meaning either there are no reports by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) or the enforcement does not involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' means less than 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. Alternatively, the shutdown could be due to voluntary closures or economic factors rather than government policy or directive. If both conditions are not met, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will the following two events take place: (1) The IMF reveals new funding commitments exceeding $400 million, and (2) The government of the Philippines refrains from shutting down Chinese-operated online trading platforms?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered YES if the following two conditions are satisfied by July 31, 2024: (1) The International Monetary Fund publicly declares one or more new funding commitments that together amount to over $400 million through official IMF channels (like their website or press releases), as reported by at least two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). These funding commitments must represent new initiatives or substantial expansions of current programs, not merely extensions of previously announced commitments. (2) There are no verified reports indicating that the Philippine government has effectively enforced a shutdown of Chinese-operated online trading platforms within the Philippines, which means either there are no reports from at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) or the enforcement does not involve official government actions resulting in the closure of a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' refers to less than 50% of the known Chinese-operated online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. Alternatively, the shutdown could arise from voluntary closures or economic circumstances rather than government policy or directive. If both conditions are not fulfilled, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Philippine government enforces a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms, or (b) the IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If neither condition is met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will one of the following take place: (a) the government of the Philippines implements a ban on online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities, or (b) the IMF reveals new financial pledges exceeding $400 million?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if one of the following scenarios occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) There are verified reports indicating that the Philippine government has effectively carried out a ban on online trading platforms managed by Chinese companies in the Philippines. This enforcement must be documented by at least two credible international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and must involve official government measures that lead to the halting of operations for a considerable number of these trading platforms. 'Considerable' in this context refers to at least 50% of the identified Chinese-operated online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The ban must stem from government policy or directive, rather than voluntary shutdowns or economic reasons. (b) The International Monetary Fund formally declares one or more new financial commitments that together exceed $400 million. These declarations must be made through official IMF channels (like their website or press releases) and must be reported by at least two reliable news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The financial commitments must represent new initiatives or significant expansions of current programs, and not the continuation of previously announced commitments. If neither scenario is fulfilled by the resolution date, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will California conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, California conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If no such referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

para_P.title: Is there a plan for California to hold a vote on abortion rights before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, California organizes a public vote aimed at establishing legal protections for abortion rights within the state. For a YES outcome, the following conditions must be fulfilled:

1. The vote must be officially declared and carried out by the state of California.
2. The main objective of the vote must be the safeguarding of abortion rights.
3. The outcomes of the vote must be disclosed through official state channels or well-known news outlets.

If no vote that meets these conditions takes place by August 31, 2024, the response will be NO. It is important to note that simply suggesting or planning a vote without executing it by the specified deadline does not suffice for a YES outcome.

question.title: Will Oregon conduct a referendum on abortion rights while California does not by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, both of the following conditions are met:

(a) Oregon officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to occur:
   1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government.
   2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
   3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

(b) California does not conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to occur:
   1. No referendum meeting the specified criteria is officially announced and conducted by the state of California by the specified date.
   2. The primary focus of any conducted referendum is not on abortion rights protection.
   3. No referendum results are publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources meeting the specified criteria.

The question will resolve as NO if either:
- Oregon does not conduct such a referendum by August 31, 2024, or
- California conducts such a referendum by August 31, 2024.

para_P.title: Will Oregon hold a vote on abortion rights while California refrains from doing so before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, both of the following conditions are satisfied:

(a) Oregon officially organizes a public vote specifically aimed at securing protections for abortion rights within the state. For this to happen:
   1. The vote must be formally announced and managed by the Oregon state government.
   2. The vote must directly address the matter of abortion rights protection.
   3. The outcomes of the vote must be publicly disclosed by official state channels or widely acknowledged news outlets.

(b) California does not organize a public vote specifically aimed at securing protections for abortion rights within the state. For this to happen:
   1. No vote that meets the specified criteria is formally announced and conducted by the state of California by the given date.
   2. The main focus of any conducted vote is not on abortion rights protection.
   3. No vote results are publicly disclosed by official state channels or widely acknowledged news outlets that meet the specified criteria.

The inquiry will be answered with NO if either:
- Oregon fails to hold such a vote by August 31, 2024, or
- California holds such a vote by August 31, 2024.

question.title: Will either California or Oregon conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, either California or Oregon conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in their respective states. The criteria for a YES resolution are as follows:

For California:
1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

For Oregon:
1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If either state meets the above criteria by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as YES. If neither state conducts such a referendum by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will either California or Oregon hold a vote on abortion rights before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, either California or Oregon holds a public vote specifically aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within their states. The conditions for a YES outcome are as follows:

For California:
1. The vote must be officially declared and carried out by the state of California.
2. The main emphasis of the vote must be on safeguarding abortion rights.
3. The outcomes of the vote must be publicly disclosed by official state sources or widely acknowledged news outlets.

For Oregon:
1. The vote must be officially declared and executed by the Oregon state government.
2. The vote must directly tackle the subject of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the vote must be publicly disclosed by official state sources or widely acknowledged news outlets.

If either state fulfills these requirements by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as YES. If neither state holds such a vote by the given date, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Israel announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Israel officially announces a decrease in its interest rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Bank of Israel declare a reduction in interest rates before July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed TRUE if the Bank of Israel formally declares a reduction in its interest rates by July 31, 2024. The declaration must be verified through official communications from the Bank of Israel or reported by at least two prominent financial news organizations (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate reduction must be a formal resolution made by the Monetary Committee and conveyed in their official announcement or press briefing following a meeting. Any conjecture regarding future rate reductions or unofficial comments from individual members of the Bank of Israel will not be considered for resolution. If no such formal declaration of an interest rate reduction is made by the resolution deadline, the inquiry resolves as FALSE.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) large protests in the United Kingdom in response to healthcare funding cuts, and (b) the Central Bank of Israel not announcing an interest rate cut?
question.body: This combined question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) There are credible reports from at least two major international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) of large protests in the United Kingdom specifically in response to the government's decision to cut healthcare funding. To qualify as 'large', the protests must involve at least 1,000 participants in a single gathering or multiple coordinated gatherings totaling at least 1,000 participants across the United Kingdom. The protests must be explicitly linked to the issue of healthcare funding cuts. If no such protests meeting these criteria occur by the specified date, or if the funding cuts are rescinded before causing such protests, this part will resolve as NO. (b) The Central Bank of Israel does not officially announce a decrease in its interest rate by July 31, 2024. The absence of an announcement must be confirmed by the lack of official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or the absence of reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC) about an interest rate cut. The interest rate cut must not be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as YES. If both conditions (a) and (b) are satisfied, the combined question resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will the following two events take place: (a) significant demonstrations in the UK against cuts to healthcare funding, and (b) the Central Bank of Israel refraining from declaring a reduction in interest rates?
para_P.body: This combined inquiry will be deemed YES if both of the following criteria are fulfilled by July 31, 2024: (a) There are reliable reports from a minimum of two prominent international news organizations (like Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) regarding significant demonstrations in the UK specifically in reaction to the government's decision to reduce healthcare funding. To be categorized as 'significant', the demonstrations must involve no fewer than 1,000 participants in a single event or multiple coordinated events aggregating at least 1,000 participants throughout the UK. The demonstrations must be directly connected to the issue of healthcare funding reductions. If no such demonstrations meeting these requirements occur by the designated date, or if the funding cuts are revoked before prompting such demonstrations, this part will resolve as NO. (b) The Central Bank of Israel does not formally declare a lowering of its interest rate by July 31, 2024. The lack of an announcement must be validated by the absence of official communications from the Central Bank of Israel or the lack of reports from at least two major financial news outlets (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC) concerning an interest rate reduction. The interest rate cut must not be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and conveyed in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation regarding future rate cuts or unofficial comments from individual members of the Central Bank of Israel will not be considered for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate reduction is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as YES. If both conditions (a) and (b) are met, the combined inquiry resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The Central Bank of Israel announces an interest rate cut, or (b) Large protests occur in the UK in response to healthcare funding cuts?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) The Central Bank of Israel officially announces a decrease in its interest rate. This announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. (b) There are credible reports from at least two major international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) of large protests in the United Kingdom specifically in response to the government's decision to cut healthcare funding. To qualify as 'large', the protests must involve at least 1,000 participants in a single gathering or multiple coordinated gatherings totaling at least 1,000 participants across the United Kingdom. The protests must be explicitly linked to the issue of healthcare funding cuts. If neither (a) nor (b) occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will one of the following take place: (a) The Central Bank of Israel declares a reduction in interest rates, or (b) Significant demonstrations happen in the UK in reaction to cuts in healthcare funding?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered as YES if one of the following happens by July 31, 2024: (a) The Central Bank of Israel makes an official declaration regarding a reduction in its interest rate. This declaration must be validated through official communications from the Central Bank of Israel or reported by at least two prominent financial news organizations (like Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate reduction must be a formal resolution made by the Monetary Committee and announced in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any conjecture about future rate reductions or unofficial remarks by individual members of the Central Bank of Israel will not be counted for resolution. (b) There are credible reports from a minimum of two major international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) regarding significant demonstrations in the United Kingdom specifically in response to the government's decision to reduce healthcare funding. To be considered 'significant', the demonstrations must include at least 1,000 attendees in a single event or multiple coordinated events totaling at least 1,000 participants throughout the United Kingdom. The demonstrations must be explicitly connected to the issue of healthcare funding cuts. If neither (a) nor (b) occurs by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

para_P.title: Will the typical interest rate for a 15-year mortgage go beyond 5.5% by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, at any time in August 2024, the typical interest rate for a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as documented by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, surpasses 5.5%. The rate must be verified by official publications from Freddie Mac or trustworthy financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any moment during August 2024, the response will be NO. To clarify, the rate needs to exceed 5.5%, not just match it.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Nevada maintains its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024, and (b) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage does not exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES only if both of the following conditions are met: (a) As of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, this condition resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law. (b) At no point during August 2024 does the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceed 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate exceeds 5.5% at any point during August 2024, this condition resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must not surpass 5.5%, it can be equal to or less than 5.5%.

para_P.title: Will both of the following take place: (a) Nevada keeps its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food employees until July 2024, and (b) the average interest rate on a 15-year mortgage does not go above 5.5% by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry resolves as YES only if both of the following conditions are satisfied: (a) As of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada stays at $11 per hour or more. This wage must be verified through official announcements from the state of Nevada or reports from at least two credible news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage drops below $11 per hour at any time before the resolution date, this condition resolves as NO. For the context of this question, 'fast food employees' refers to workers in fast food establishments as defined by Nevada state legislation. (b) At no time during August 2024 does the average interest rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceed 5.5%. This rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or trustworthy financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate goes beyond 5.5% at any point during August 2024, this condition resolves as NO. To clarify, the rate must not exceed 5.5%, and it can be equal to or lower than 5.5%.

question.title: Will either the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024, or will Nevada maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following conditions is met: (a) At any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it. (b) As of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. 'Fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

para_P.title: Is it possible that the average interest rate for a 15-year mortgage will go over 5.5% by August 2024, or will the state of Nevada keep its minimum wage for fast food employees at $11 per hour until the end of July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if at least one of the following scenarios occurs: (a) At any moment during August 2024, the average interest rate for a 15-year fixed mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. This rate must be validated by official sources from Freddie Mac or credible financial news outlets like Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must exceed 5.5%, not just match it. (b) By July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada is still set at $11 per hour or more. This wage must be verified through official announcements from the state of Nevada or reports from at least two trustworthy news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is lowered to below $11 per hour at any time before the resolution date, the answer will be NO. 'Fast food workers' refers to those employed in fast food establishments as defined by Nevada state legislation.

question.title: Will PepsiCo report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will there be a rise in North American demand for Tostitos by PepsiCo by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if, on or before July 31, 2024, PepsiCo indicates a growth in North American demand for its Tostitos brand relative to the demand figures from the second quarter of 2023. This increase must be substantiated through official earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and corroborated by a minimum of two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The growth in demand should be either explicitly mentioned or clearly suggested in the company's financial disclosures or official announcements. If no such growth is reported by the designated date, or if PepsiCo indicates a persistent decline or stagnation in Tostitos demand in North America, the inquiry will conclude as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) U.S. weekly jobless claims exceed 200,000 for four consecutive weeks by August 2024, and (b) PepsiCo not report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. Only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered for this condition. (b) By July 31, 2024, PepsiCo does not report an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. This includes scenarios where no such increase is reported, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America. The absence of an increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal. If both conditions are not met, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of these events will take place: (a) the weekly jobless claims in the U.S. will surpass 200,000 for four straight weeks by August 2024, and (b) PepsiCo will not announce a rise in North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if both of the following stipulations are satisfied: (a) The weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as documented by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceed 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any time from now until August 31, 2024. Only the official figures released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be taken into account for this requirement. (b) By July 31, 2024, PepsiCo does not disclose an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand relative to the demand noted in the second quarter of 2023. This encompasses situations where no increase is reported, or if PepsiCo indicates a continued decrease or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America. The lack of an increase must be validated through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and confirmed by at least two credible news outlets such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal. If either of the conditions is unmet, the inquiry will be deemed negative.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by mid-2024: an increase in North American demand for Tostitos or U.S. jobless claims exceeding 200,000 for four consecutive weeks?
question.body:
(a) PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 31, 2024, compared to the second quarter of 2023. This must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo, reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. The question will resolve as NO if this condition is not met within the specified timeframe. Only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered.

para_P.title: By the middle of 2024, will there be an uptick in Tostitos demand in North America or will U.S. unemployment claims surpass 200,000 for four straight weeks?
para_P.body:
(a) PepsiCo must announce an uptick in demand for its Tostitos product in North America by July 31, 2024, in comparison to the second quarter of 2023. This must be substantiated through official earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo, as reported by at least two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The increase in demand should be clearly stated or strongly suggested in the company’s financial disclosures or official communications. If there is no report of such an increase by the specified date, or if PepsiCo indicates a continued decrease or stagnation in Tostitos demand in North America, this aspect will conclude as NO.

(b) The weekly initial jobless claims in the U.S., as recorded by the U.S. Department of Labor, must exceed 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any time from now until August 31, 2024. This question will conclude as NO if this criterion is not satisfied within the given timeframe. Only official statistics released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be taken into account.

question.title: Will a court rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no such ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court without a formal ruling, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires a ruling to be made on the matter of liability.

para_P.title: Will there be a decision from a court regarding the responsibility of a significant hotel chain operator by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by August 31, 2024, a legal court provides a decision on whether a significant hotel chain operator is accountable for negligence or gross negligence concerning an event that caused substantial damage or loss. The decision must be officially recorded in court documents and reported by at least two prominent news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no decision is made by the specified date, or if the matter is resolved outside of court without an official ruling, the outcome will be NO. It is important to note that this question does not necessitate the court to determine the operator's liability; it only requires that a ruling be made regarding the issue of liability.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure shows a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024, and (b) No court rules on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as YES if the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame. 

(b) This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, no court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. This includes cases where the matter is settled out of court without a formal ruling. If a ruling occurs by the resolution date, documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times), the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires no ruling to be made on the matter of liability.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) The Federal Reserve's favored inflation indicator indicates a monthly rise surpassing 0.5% by July 2024, and (b) No legal decision regarding the accountability of a significant hotel chain operator is made by August 2024?

(a) This inquiry will be answered affirmatively if the Federal Reserve's favored inflation indicator (usually the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) records a month-over-month increase exceeding 0.5% in any month from October 2023 to July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially announced by the Federal Reserve or a pertinent U.S. government body (like the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and covered by at least two credible financial news organizations (for example, Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is documented during this timeframe, the inquiry will be answered negatively. It is important to note that this question is concerned with the month-over-month variation, rather than year-over-year or any other duration. 

(b) This inquiry will be answered affirmatively if, by August 31, 2024, no court of law delivers a verdict on whether a major hotel chain operator is responsible for negligence or gross negligence concerning an incident that caused significant damage or loss. This encompasses situations where the issue is resolved outside of court without a formal verdict. If a ruling is made by the resolution date, recorded in official court documents and reported by at least two prominent news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times), the inquiry will be answered negatively. It should be noted that this question does not necessitate the court to determine the operator's liability; it only requires that no ruling is made regarding the issue of liability.

question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of Australia announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Reserve Bank of Australia declare a reduction in interest rates by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if the Reserve Bank of Australia formally declares a reduction in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The declaration must be validated through official communications from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reported by at least two significant financial news outlets (including Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The reduction in interest rates must be an official decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and conveyed in their official statement or press conference after a meeting. Any conjecture regarding future rate reductions or unofficial comments from individual RBA members will not be considered for resolution. If there is no such official declaration of a reduction in interest rates by the resolution date, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the U.S. Education Department implement a plan to offer student loan payment holidays by July 2024 AND will the Reserve Bank of Australia not announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has successfully implemented a plan to offer payment holidays for student loan borrowers. The implementation must be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must be a new initiative aimed at offering payment holidays for a significant number of student loan borrowers. If no such implementation occurs by the resolution date, or if the plan is blocked by further legal challenges, this part resolves as NO. (2) The Reserve Bank of Australia does not officially announce a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The resolution will be based on the absence of any official statements from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC) confirming a rate cut. If there is no formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting about a rate cut, this part resolves as YES. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. If an official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO. Only if both (1) and (2) are satisfied will the overall question resolve as YES.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will the United Food and Commercial Workers publicly support a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election?

The support must be validated through official statements from UFCW or reported by at least two credible news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The support must explicitly show backing for a specific candidate in the 2024 presidential contest. If no such support is given or publicly declared by the resolution date, the inquiry will resolve as NO. It is important to note that this question does not take into account hypothetical or speculative endorsements; only formal, public endorsements will be used for resolution.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Google resolves a major workers' strike by July 2024 and (b) the United Food and Commercial Workers not endorse any candidate for the 2024 US presidential election by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

1. Google resolves a major workers' strike by reaching an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. The strike must involve at least 1,000 participants and last for at least one week. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Google and the involved union, and reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

2. The United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) does not publicly endorse any candidate for the 2024 United States presidential election. This will be based on the absence of official UFCW statements or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal) confirming an endorsement.

If both conditions are met by the resolution date, the question resolves as YES. If either or both conditions are not met, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will both of the following take place: (a) Google successfully ends a significant workers' strike by July 2024 and (b) the United Food and Commercial Workers refrain from endorsing any candidate for the 2024 US presidential election by July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry is answered with YES if both of the following criteria are satisfied by July 31, 2024:

1. Google successfully concludes a major workers' strike by reaching a consensus with unionized employees, leading to the cessation of a notable strike. The strike must involve a minimum of 1,000 participants and persist for at least one week. The resolution must be validated by official announcements from both Google and the participating union, and covered by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

2. The United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) does not officially support any candidate for the 2024 United States presidential election. This determination will rely on the lack of official UFCW announcements or reports from at least two reputable news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal) confirming any endorsement.

If both criteria are fulfilled by the resolution date, the inquiry resolves as YES. If either or both criteria are not fulfilled, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The United Food and Commercial Workers endorse a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election, or (b) Google resolve a major workers' strike?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024:

(a) The United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) publicly endorse a candidate for the 2024 United States presidential election. The endorsement must be confirmed through official UFCW statements or reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The endorsement must clearly indicate support for a specific candidate in the 2024 presidential race. If no such endorsement is made or publicly announced by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not consider hypothetical or speculative endorsements; only official, public endorsements will be considered for resolution.

(b) Google reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Google workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Google and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is there a possibility that by July 2024, either (a) the United Food and Commercial Workers will publicly support a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election, or (b) Google will successfully negotiate an end to a significant workers' strike?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if one of the following happens by July 31, 2024:

(a) The United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) officially backs a candidate for the 2024 United States presidential election. The endorsement must be validated through formal UFCW announcements or reported by at least two reliable news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The endorsement must explicitly show support for a particular candidate in the 2024 presidential contest. If no such endorsement is made or publicly disclosed by the resolution deadline, the inquiry will resolve as NO. Note that this question does not take into account any hypothetical or speculative endorsements; only concrete, public endorsements will be evaluated for resolution.

(b) Google comes to a settlement with unionized employees, leading to the conclusion of a major strike. For the resolution to be deemed valid:
   1. The strike must involve a significant number of Google employees (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must persist for a minimum of one week.
   3. The resolution must be verified by official statements from both Google and the relevant union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news agencies (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution that meets all these conditions is achieved by the specified date, or if no major strike takes place, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of India impose new regulatory curbs on Yes Bank's lending by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) announces new regulatory curbs specifically targeting Yes Bank's lending practices. The announcement must be confirmed by official statements from the RBI or reported by at least two major Indian financial news outlets (such as Economic Times, Mint, or Business Standard). These new curbs must be distinct from any existing regulations as of October 1, 2023, and must directly impact Yes Bank's lending operations. If no such new curbs are announced by the specified date, or if any announced curbs do not specifically target Yes Bank's lending practices, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will new lending restrictions be placed on Yes Bank by the Reserve Bank of India before August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, on or before August 31, 2024, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) reveals new lending restrictions that are specifically aimed at Yes Bank. The confirmation must come from official RBI announcements or be reported by at least two prominent Indian financial news sources (such as Economic Times, Mint, or Business Standard). These restrictions must be separate from any current regulations as of October 1, 2023, and must have a direct effect on Yes Bank's lending activities. If no such restrictions are declared by the deadline, or if any declared restrictions do not specifically focus on Yes Bank's lending, the inquiry will be deemed negative.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Food and Agriculture Organization announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024, and (b) The Reserve Bank of India refrain from imposing new regulatory curbs on Yes Bank's lending by August 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

(a) By July 31, 2024, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official FAO channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not exceed $400 million, this part resolves as NO.

(b) By August 31, 2024, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) does not announce any new regulatory curbs specifically targeting Yes Bank's lending practices. This includes the absence of any official statements from the RBI or reports by at least two major Indian financial news outlets (such as Economic Times, Mint, or Business Standard) confirming such curbs. If no new curbs are announced by the specified date, or if any announced curbs do not specifically target Yes Bank's lending practices, this part resolves as YES. If new curbs are announced and confirmed, this part resolves as NO.

The overall question resolves as YES only if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES. If either part resolves as NO, the overall question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) The Food and Agriculture Organization will declare new funding commitments exceeding $400 million by July 2024, and (b) The Reserve Bank of India will not introduce new regulatory restrictions on Yes Bank's lending by August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered affirmatively if both of the following criteria are satisfied: 

(a) By July 31, 2024, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) makes an official announcement regarding one or more new funding commitments that in total surpass $400 million. The announcement(s) must be disseminated through official FAO channels (such as their website or press releases) and covered by at least two credible news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must represent new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not merely continuations of previously announced funding. Should there be no such announcement by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not exceed $400 million, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) By August 31, 2024, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) does not issue any new regulatory restrictions specifically aimed at Yes Bank's lending practices. This includes the lack of any official statements from the RBI or reports from at least two prominent Indian financial news outlets (such as Economic Times, Mint, or Business Standard) confirming such restrictions. If no new restrictions are declared by the specified date, or if any announced restrictions do not specifically target Yes Bank's lending practices, this part will resolve as YES. If new restrictions are announced and confirmed, this part will resolve as NO.

The overall question will resolve as YES only if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES. If either part resolves as NO, the overall question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will the Reserve Bank of India either implement new restrictions on Yes Bank's lending practices, or will the Food and Agriculture Organization declare new funding pledges exceeding $400 million by July 2024?

question.title: Will New York hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, New York officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a positive resolution:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the New York state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if:

1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it takes place within the specified timeframe.

para_P.title: Will there be a public vote in New York regarding abortion rights before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, New York officially carries out a public vote specifically aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within the state. For a positive determination:

1. The public vote must be officially declared and executed by the New York state authorities.
2. The public vote must directly address the matter of safeguarding abortion rights.
3. The outcomes of the public vote must be disclosed through official state communications or well-known news outlets.

The inquiry will be deemed negative if:

1. No such public vote takes place by August 31, 2024.
2. A scheduled public vote is cancelled or delayed beyond the mentioned date.
3. A public vote occurs, but it does not specifically aim at establishing protections for abortion rights.

Note: This inquiry does not take into account the results of the public vote, only whether it is conducted within the given timeframe.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Georgia holds a referendum on abortion rights by July 2024 (b) New York does not hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

(a) Georgia officially conducts a statewide referendum specifically on the topic of enshrining abortion rights in the state constitution by July 31, 2024. The referendum must be formally announced by the Georgia state government and verified by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, NPR, or major Georgia-based news outlets). The referendum must be open to all eligible voters in Georgia and focus primarily on abortion rights. If no such referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if the referendum is canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, this condition will be considered not met.

(b) New York does not officially conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights by August 31, 2024. This condition will be met if:
   1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
   2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
   3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.
   
This question will resolve as NO if either Georgia does not hold the specified referendum by July 31, 2024, or New York does hold such a referendum by August 31, 2024, or both conditions are not met.

para_P.title: Will both of the following events take place: (a) Georgia conducts a referendum on abortion rights before July 2024 (b) New York refrains from holding a referendum on abortion rights before August 2024?

(b) New York does not officially carry out a public referendum specifically aimed at establishing safeguards for abortion rights by August 31, 2024. This requirement will be satisfied if:
   1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
   2. A scheduled referendum is canceled or postponed past the specified date.
   3. A referendum is conducted, but it does not specifically target the establishment of protections for abortion rights.
   
This inquiry will be answered with NO if either Georgia fails to hold the specified referendum by July 31, 2024, or New York conducts such a referendum by August 31, 2024, or if both conditions are not fulfilled.

question.title: Will either New York or Georgia hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:

The question will resolve as NO if neither of these referendums occurs by their respective deadlines, or if any planned referendum is canceled or postponed beyond the specified dates.

para_P.title: Will either New York or Georgia hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
para_P.body:

The inquiry will be answered negatively if neither of these votes takes place by their respective deadlines, or if any scheduled vote is canceled or delayed beyond the specified dates.

question.title: Will Washington's Medicaid expansion program enroll over 450,000 people by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if Washington's Medicaid expansion program has enrolled more than 450,000 residents by July 31, 2024. The enrollment figures must be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the enrollment does not exceed 450,000 by the resolution date, or if reliable data is not available, the question resolves as NO. The enrollment count refers to the total number of individuals newly covered under the Medicaid expansion program, not including those who were previously eligible for Medicaid.

para_P.title: Will more than 450,000 individuals be enrolled in Washington's Medicaid expansion program by the end of July 2024?

If the total enrollment does not exceed 450,000 by the specified resolution date, or if trustworthy data is unavailable, the inquiry will be answered with a NO. The enrollment figures pertain to the count of individuals newly included in the Medicaid expansion program, excluding those who were already eligible for Medicaid.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The Reserve Bank of Australia announces an interest rate cut and (b) Washington's Medicaid expansion program enrolls 450,000 people or fewer?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) The Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. (b) Washington's Medicaid expansion program has enrolled 450,000 residents or fewer. The enrollment figures must be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The enrollment count refers to the total number of individuals newly covered under the Medicaid expansion program, not including those who were previously eligible for Medicaid. If either condition is not met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Biogen's Alzheimer's treatment Leqembi receive European conditional marketing approval by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if Biogen's Alzheimer's treatment Leqembi receives conditional marketing approval from the European Medicines Agency (EMA) by July 31, 2024. The approval must be officially announced by the EMA and reported by at least two reputable news sources. If no such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the EMA explicitly rejects the approval, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question is based on the regulatory process as of October 1, 2023, and does not take into account any specific committee recommendations or decisions made after this date.

para_P.title: Will Biogen's Alzheimer's medication Leqembi obtain conditional marketing authorization in Europe by July 2024?

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Medicare's negotiated drug prices include a major diabetes medication by August 2024 and (b) Biogen's Alzheimer's treatment Leqembi does not receive European conditional marketing approval by July 2024?

This must be confirmed by official announcements from Medicare, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, or another relevant U.S. government agency, and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal).
(b) Biogen's Alzheimer's treatment Leqembi does not receive conditional marketing approval from the European Medicines Agency (EMA) by July 31, 2024, or the EMA explicitly rejects the approval. This must be confirmed by the absence of an official announcement by the EMA and not reported by at least two reputable news sources. 
If both (a) and (b) occur as described, the question resolves as YES. If either (a) or (b) does not occur as described, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Are both of the following events going to take place: (a) Medicare's negotiated prices for drugs will feature a significant diabetes medication by August 2024, and (b) Biogen's Alzheimer's drug Leqembi will not gain conditional marketing authorization in Europe by July 2024?

question.title: Will Alibaba Group resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Alibaba Group reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Alibaba Group workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Alibaba Group come to an agreement to end a significant workers' strike by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with a YES if Alibaba Group successfully negotiates with the unionized workforce, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For the answer to be deemed valid:

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Mexico announce an interest rate cut by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Mexico officially announces an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. Note that the actual implementation date of the rate cut can be after August 31, 2024, as long as the announcement itself occurs by that date. The interest rate in question refers to the target for the overnight interbank interest rate, which is the Central Bank of Mexico's primary tool for monetary policy.

This statement must be issued through official company channels (like press releases, investor relations announcements, or official social media accounts) or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, Wall Street Journal). The increase in AI-related personnel must be clearly articulated and not merely inferred from general hiring strategies. If neither declaration occurs by the specified deadline, or if the respective requirements for each declaration are not fulfilled, the inquiry will be resolved as NO.

question.title: Will another U.S. state implement a 72-hour waiting period for voting registration by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, at least one additional U.S. state (other than Maine and those that already have such measures) implements a mandatory 72-hour waiting period for voting registration. The implementation must be confirmed through official state legislation or government announcements, and reported by at least two major national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, CNN, Fox News, or MSNBC). The waiting period must specifically be 72 hours; longer or shorter periods do not qualify. If no additional state adopts such a measure by the resolution date, or if the implementations are for different waiting periods, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will any other U.S. state establish a 72-hour delay for voter registration by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if, by August 31, 2024, at least one more U.S. state (aside from Maine and those that have already enacted such policies) enacts a compulsory 72-hour delay for voter registration. The delay must be precisely 72 hours; any longer or shorter durations do not qualify. If no further state adopts such a policy by the resolution date, or if the implementations involve different delay periods, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Ohio removes the work requirement from its Medicaid plan by July 2024 (b) No additional U.S. state implements a 72-hour waiting period for voting registration by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By July 31, 2024, the state of Ohio officially announces the removal of the work requirement from its Medicaid plan. The change must be confirmed through official state announcements or reported by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The work requirement refers to the condition that beneficiaries must work or engage in other qualifying activities to receive Medicaid benefits. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the work requirement remains in place, this part resolves as NO. (2) By August 31, 2024, no additional U.S. state (other than Maine and those that already have such measures) implements a mandatory 72-hour waiting period for voting registration. If any additional state adopts such a measure by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO. The implementation must be confirmed through official state legislation or government announcements, and reported by at least two major national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, CNN, Fox News, or MSNBC). The waiting period must specifically be 72 hours; longer or shorter periods do not qualify. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will U.S. previously occupied home sales increase for three consecutive months by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are three consecutive months where sales of previously occupied homes in the U.S. show an increase compared to the previous month. The data must be verified by reputable sources such as the National Association of Realtors or other widely recognized real estate market analysts. The increases must be reported in terms of seasonally adjusted annual rates. If no such consecutive monthly increases are reported by the resolution date, or if only one or two months show an increase, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will there be a rise in sales of previously owned homes in the U.S. for three straight months by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are three successive months in which the sales of previously owned homes in the United States demonstrate growth compared to the prior month. The information must be validated by credible sources such as the National Association of Realtors or other highly regarded real estate market analysts. The increases should be reported in terms of seasonally adjusted annual rates. If no such consecutive monthly rises are indicated by the resolution date, or if only one or two months reflect an increase, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Medicare's negotiated drug prices include a major cholesterol medication by August 2024, and (b) U.S. previously occupied home sales fail to increase for three consecutive months by July 2024?
question.body: (a) This part resolves as YES if the newly negotiated drug prices for Medicare include a major cholesterol medication confirmed to take effect by August 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official announcements by Medicare, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, or another relevant U.S. government agency. The inclusion of the medication must be reported by at least two reputable news sources such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal. (b) This part resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are not three consecutive months where sales of previously occupied homes in the U.S. show an increase compared to the previous month. The data must be verified by reputable sources such as the National Association of Realtors or other widely recognized real estate market analysts. The increases must be reported in terms of seasonally adjusted annual rates. The combined question resolves as YES if both (a) and (b) occur as described.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) a significant cholesterol drug will be part of Medicare's negotiated prices by August 2024, and (b) sales of previously owned homes in the U.S. will not show an increase for three straight months by July 2024?
